projects.elevator_pitch: Earthseed is an immersive, intimate storytelling structure powered by interactive stars, ecological architecture, and reciprocal oral history excerpts that speak on abortion, gender transitions, and kinship.
projects.description: Historically, archives have been sites of erasure and capture, not sovereignty. Earthseed aims to reimagine an archive where stories are medicine. Earthseed is an intimate storytelling structure powered by interactive stars, pinecone architecture, and oral history interviews that speak on abortion, gender transitions, and care work. Inspired by sweat lodge ceremony and pinecones’ protective form, Earthseed is an experimental immersive archive that houses the intimate land/body stories shared between myself and longtime collaborator, Ximena Violante.
projects.user_scenario: Users are invited to enter pinecone and hear stories. Installation is to be experience one person at a time.
projects.technical_system: Installation is a kinetic pinecone that opens and closes according to its environment. Attached on hinged to base architecture, pinecone scales will move at different stages through gearmotors and string. Once granted permission, user can enter dark space and touch LED "stars" that will trigger different oral histories through capacitive sensors and p5 javascript.

projects.elevator_pitch: The history of computer science can be traced back to weaving. Touch-to-touch network is a speculative exploration of a question: what if, rather than embodying the efficiency of automation brought by machines, communication technology embraced our humanness instead by serving our desire to touch, and acknowledging its deep-rooted relationship to weaving soft materials meant for our bodies?
projects.description: When you walk through a forest, you can feel the grass beneath your feet, smell the earth, hear and feel the wind weaving between the trees. When you are sitting at your desk to work, everything feels smooth. Every corner is rounded to precision, every metallic surface brushed to its maximum aesthetic potential. I smell nothing through the machine-purified air, there is no wind, and I hear only the taps and clicks of body hitting machine.
projects.user_scenario: People are welcome to come walk around and touch the project.
projects.technical_system: fleece yarn (tufted and knotted), conductive fabric, old coffee burlap bags, shoddy, 1.5v vibrating motors, Raspberry Pi Pico Ws, 4.5v AA battery packs

projects.elevator_pitch: _TITLE_explores the dual meanings of the word subject: to come into being as a subject and to be subjected to.
projects.description:
My thesis research investigates human-adjacent and non-human materials to flesh out my fascination with the corporeal. My guiding question is a selfish one: How are our bodies coerced without our knowledge? My neck tenses when I receive an unpleasant email. I run and rush, rather than enjoy my stroll, when late for another arbitrary start to the work day, saving perhaps a minute or two. In what ways are we affected by external  processes and systems? When do we see ourselves in non-human forms?
 

Taking these moments of disconnect from our bodies, I wonder how we might recognize ourselves outside of ourselves. How might objects, such as relics imbued with power or amulets worn for luck, have agency? How do we find, and/or impose, the distributed person in objects and materials, beyond the body-boundary? Activated by these questions, I began the process of trying to invert the traditional subject-object relationship through kinetic sculpture.
projects.background: Mariona Berenguer’s sculpture About Desire and Mire Lee’s exhibit Black Sun guided my form, specifically their use of human body-adjacent materials and motors. Alfred Gell’s Art and Agency informed my conceptual grounding of the project. His notion of exuviae elaborates that personhood isn’t just solely ours but rather is distributed and extends outwards into the world through a variety of artifacts and technologies. Arnold H. Modell’s article “The Body in Psychoanalysis and the Origin of Fantasy'' illuminated that my interest was not purely centered on the body but also the psychic life of objects. This subtle shift untangled confusions I had regarding my fixation with using a more visceral form in my sculpture: physicality and the body provide the strong metaphorical understanding that our physical life draws upon for meaning-making. Showing the body provides easier access into a more abstract psychic life.
projects.technical_system: air pumps, silicone, physical computing, 3d printing

projects.elevator_pitch: interdepend.net is a website that is only accessible when a human generates enough power to start the server.
projects.description: interdepend.net is a website that is only accessible when a human generates enough power to start the server. The system creates a relationship between one side of the screen and the other, involving both the human power generator and any number of human browsers. The browsers will not be able to view the site without the generator, and the generator will not see the result of their labor without the browsers. The ensuing relationship is one of mutual dependency and reciprocity. It is the manifestation of man’s inability to get by alone.
projects.background: interdepend.net is inspired by alternatively-powered, self-hosted web works like Low Tech Magazine and Solar Protocol. It takes inspiration from Olia Lialina’s artwork “Summer” (2013), which weaves friendships into its infrastructure. I thank Tung-Hui Hu for instigating my critical thinking on the materiality of the internet (A Prehistory of The Cloud, 2015) and digital labor (Digital Lethargy, 2022). I thank Mierle Laderman Ukeles for teaching me the importance of maintenance labor, which has forever changed the way I think about social infrastructure and acts of service. I also owe thanks to Theo Ellin Ballew and countless other net artists for opening my eyes to the browser’s potential as an artistic medium. Lastly, I am indebted to all those who have shared technical documentation online, and those who have dared to ask the void for help.
projects.user_scenario: People will be invited to manually power the generator that will provide energy for the server.
projects.technical_system:
Hardware: Raspberry Pi 4 server, Witty Pi Hat 4 add-on board, portable lithium battery, hand crank power generator. 
Software: P5.js, HTML/CSS/JS, Node.js, socket.io, Firebase, shell scripts, systemd service files, Python.

projects.elevator_pitch: A desktop object that creates existing ambient companionship.
projects.description:
This project explores the topic of ambient.

 Ambiance is happening in our lives at any given moment, in the past decade ambient media has become a new norm, from Lofi Hip-Hop girl to simply a fan in the room.  A lot of us need ambient background noise these days.

Rather than the issues of our attention span, this project explores the concept that ambient media/items serve companionship. How can ambient be served as companionship? 


The same companionship I seek in ambient media, I also find in my relationship with some of my objects. The tools I use as an extension of my body or other objects that support me emotionally through different days of my life. We have attachments to some of our objects.The value is not from the object itself, but the relationship we have with them. 

This project is an attempt at creating something that can bring some intimacy to people the same way ambient stuff and some of my objects brought me.

projects.elevator_pitch: A geo-based art collection game to help you explore the city.
projects.description:
How can we engage people to explore and learn from a city in fun and meaningful ways?

Embarking on a project to encourage exploration and learning in a city is driven by the recognition that, while we live in a diverse world, the rapid pace of modern life often keeps us from truly observing our surroundings. 

This initiative is rooted in the value of curiosity, a powerful force that transforms the ordinary into the extraordinary. It aims to reignite the sense of wonder in people, encouraging them to delve deeper into the stories, cultures, and histories that shape urban landscapes. In doing so, it creates opportunities for discovery and enriches our understanding of the places we live in.

This project is more than an exploration of urban spaces; it's a platform for connecting people. As individuals engage with their city, they also connect, turning the urban environment into a shared space of learning and experience. It bridges cultural and social divides, fostering a community of learners and explorers united by their shared journeys. Ultimately, this project celebrates the diversity of our world and the inquisitive human spirit, creating meaningful connections and a deeper appreciation of our cities and ourselves.
projects.user_scenario: People will use this service as physical hardware or a phone app
projects.technical_system: A mobile app with a physical GPS tracking device will guide you to the art piece around you. I am building a full-stack mobile app with React Native and Strapi. Using an ESP32 chip with a compass and GPS module to get real-time data.

projects.elevator_pitch: Provenance is a tactile-audio narrative experience for one person in the dark. It follows the story of a girl who finds a mysterious artifact and the search for its true home.
projects.description: Provenance is a tactile-audio narrative experience for one person in the dark. It begins in total darkness, with pieces the audience can touch and manipulate. As they move the pieces into place, the audience begins to hear spoken narration that tells them a story. There is a girl, and a mysterious artifact, and her quest to find the place where it belongs. As the audience explores and discover more of the story, the sensory world expands as well, adding more sound, more things to touch, and beginning to introduce light.
projects.background: This project was inspired by a wide array of influences, including escape room experiences with a strong story component and live-action roleplaying games that work with ritual and tactile interaction. In addition to thinking about related works, I considered sources around haptic perception in the dark, relationship to peripersonal space (the graspable/manipulatable area around someone), and meaning-making through exploration. I read about how people make sense of the space around them, how they learn rules through designed environment setup, and how they construct their understanding of what happens in a story, with the hope of making an experience that brings all these together.
projects.user_scenario: The project is meant for one person at a time. The audience enters the dark space, sits down, and feels around them to discover the tactile components that trigger story narration.
projects.technical_system: The tactile part of the piece is built from a combination of mechanical and electronic components. The electronic sensors and motors are all connected through an Arduino, which talks to a computer through serial communication. The computer runs a Python program that handles the core logic of the interactions and plays sound through a speaker.

projects.elevator_pitch:
In an enclosed room where one holds their keys,
the flesh-pink intimacy becomes sticky
a bed splitted to half,
placed at the two poles like two cells divided from the parental whole,
with membranes form between,
dermis like analog screens,
who am I when you are present,
am I still the same person, the same body 
that takes up its own space,
or is it eaten by your invasiveness,
What is this invisible membrane 
that veils partially of your presence from me? 
I am and I become myself,
With your present,
and we are two wholesome beings
body and mind
projects.description: At the genesis of human life, as meiosis unfolds, the delineation between individuals emerges, safeguarding the spectrum of diversity. Just as cells diverge from their parental origins, our distinctiveness crystallizes through the genesis of membranes. The membrane separates us into both subjects and objects. Through the membranes that tear us apart, we get closer to each other. Naming this project as Cytokinesis, which is the stage in meiosis where nuclear envelopes are formed while a cell’s cytoplasm divides to form two new cells, this project aims to cherish the membrane between the reciprocality developed in intimate relationships. With the intertwined call and response experience cultivated between 2 participants, Cytokinesis envisions a beautiful embodiment and a carnal adherence of both equilibrium and uniqueness. Built upon the premise of recreated soft, skin-like membranes with the encounter of hard metal bed frame that signifies an absent body,  the project entails a world of reciprocal affects and twist and turns that cumulates in relationships
projects.user_scenario: 2 people per experience. It is a call & response experience where one person's interaction with the physical installation on their end triggers movements in the other part of installation.
projects.technical_system: By using MQTT, distance sensors and motors to establish the call and response, real-time communication between the two bed frame experiences for the 2 people, I aim to embody the elastic, reciprocal relationship that always plays with a secure distance. Whenever one participant appraoches their end of the sensor, the data will be transmitted to the other installation through MQTT, triggering the motors their to drag the soft materials, and vice versa. In terms of the soft materials, Agar agar based bio material with combination of silicone casted soft material are incorporated to visualize the body, which is the crucial chiasm of such meandering journey

projects.elevator_pitch: Storytime is an interactive storytelling experience that uses toylike miniatures with projection mapping and on-screen animations to create a surreal environment to bring a digitally illustrated story into the physical world.
projects.description: Storytime is an interactive storytelling experience that uses toylike miniatures with projection mapping and on-screen animations to create a surreal environment to bring a digitally illustrated story into the physical world.
projects.background: The project started by exploring color theory, how colors relate to our emotions, and how filmmakers and artists successfully use them to convey moods, atmospheres, and feelings without saying it explicitly. Halfway through the first semester, after talking to my advisor and other faculty, I decided to change to a project that still uses color theory as a storytelling tool instead of the experience being an information session on color. As a passionate 2D animator, I also wanted to use this medium to portray a story that acts as an example. Inspired by various movies (live-action and animated) and role-playing games set in surreal worlds, I created the story of 'Whispering Windows,' which is aesthetically beautiful yet haunting at the same time. It uses toy-like miniatures, surreal illustrated animations, colors, and music to bring to life a digitally animated story into the physical world. The project is a combination of my favorite projects that I've done as part of ITP, borrowing an element from each, namely 2D animation, non-linear storytelling, projecting mapping, automaton animations, digital fabrication, and making a playful interactive experience.
projects.user_scenario: People will make choices in the main story via simple buttons and they might interact indirectly by controlling the light and colors of the projection.
projects.technical_system: It gives users limited scope to use buttons/keys to trigger different animations via either unity or js on a screen that's hidden behind a miniature building, while other sensors control the color and lighting of the projections mapped onto the building.

projects.elevator_pitch: Burp World Online is an exploration of sound design as interface design. By reimagining the online social space as one that is free of the distraction of screens and visual social biases, it fosters a new way of interacting with the computer and with each other through sound, voice, and listening.
projects.description:
Burps have long been disrespected as an unserious form of sonic media. Labelled "vulgar" and "classless", the art of the belch is often responded to with vitriol and grimaces. 

For a large number of people burping is a way of life. Whether it be IBS or an addiction to Diet Cokes, those who know the truth of living with gas know that there's no holding it in. Be sneaky and pray for an inconspicuous release or disgust the people around you, it's a situation that gassy people can never win. That is until Burp World Online.

Burp World Online is a safe haven for burpers and belchers, where gas is celebrated and not criticised. 

I've found a gap in the market: there's no social media platform designed for the luscious sonic qualities of burps. Text based social media platforms like Twitter fall short, relying on the untrustworthy phoenetic interpretation of the burper. Video platforms like YouTube add too much bulk around the short and sweet burp. Platforms like Instagram and TikTok prioritise people that are hot, not the best burpers.

Burp World Online is made for the serious burper, using a fully sound-based user interface that respects the righteous burp. We've made it casual, spontaneous, and effortless to share your burp with the world.
projects.background:
Burp World Online uses a "For You Page" style of content organisation, relying on an algorithm to populate the main feed.

Burp World Online is heavily influenced by voice apps such as WeChat, Whatsapp, Clubhouse, and the voice message feature in iMessage. Similar user generated podcasting apps include Cappuccino, Amp, and Spotify for Podcasters (fka Anchor).

This project takes into account the legacy and sociological impacts of sound based interactions, including voice assistants, DTMF Auto Attendants, telephone operators, and radio programming. This project also investigates the realm of sound design, especially as it pertains to game and interface design. 

The development of Burp World Online investigated the world of audio Javascript libraries. Initial developments attempted to use Tone.js as the basis of UI elements but it was found that the timeline-based workflows were too limiting to create the variation in audio element playback. Development shifted to a lower level scope, working directly with the Web Audio API and ultimately resulted in the creation of Jogg.js.
projects.technical_system:
Burp World Online runs on Node.js with Express, using Firebase for authentication and storage, and uses a MongoDB database. [burpworld.online](burpworld.online) is deployed on Digital Ocean

The web client is built with HTML, CSS, JS, and uses [Jogg.js](), a custom-built Javascript abstraction layer built on top of the Web Audio API designed to create interactive audio interfaces.

![Tech Stack Diagram](./doc/images/tech-stack-diagram.png)
projects.project_references: "Designing Sound" by Andy Farnell

projects.elevator_pitch: How does communication technology affect one’s ability to be vulnerable? The term vulnerable, within the scope of this thesis, addresses the willingness for reciprocity and self-disclosure. How do you choose to tell someone you love them: texting them a heart emoji, texting them you love them, sending a voice note, calling them, or telling them in-person?
projects.description:
Through a series of experiments, Social Protocols examines how communication technology affects one’s ability to be vulnerable. In order to explore vulnerability, the project uses roleplaying, interactive web experiments, and re-enactment as methodologies to understand how medium and the message play hand in hand in shaping a conversation. This idea of embodied vulnerability can be seen through participants becoming a ‘performer’. Re-enactment offers the participant a chance to be vulnerable and reflect. Does the medium of communication change what we say and how we say it? 
Is it possible to construct the perfect conditions for technology to mediate vulnerability? In order to structure my creative research, the experiments investigate physical space, digital identity, physical vulnerability, affordances of media, physical contexts, access, and time. The experiments, ‘A-Home-Page’, ‘DMs in Public’, ‘Algorithms of Care’, ‘Pillow Talk’, invite participants to reach a point of discomfort in order to choose whether to be vulnerable.
projects.background: The development of communication technology has primarily moved towards convenience rather than the quality of conversation. Of course, while there are a number of platforms that are outliers, like BeReal or Letterloop, our standard means of conversing remains the same.
projects.technical_system: Websockets; WebRTC

projects.elevator_pitch: A web application to engage local communities with issues of transparency & consent raised by the expansion of automated policing infrastructure in Brooklyn, New York.
projects.description: Rebuttal Tracker is a tool for real-time data exploration and for mapping routes around public surveillance infrastructure. By inserting a person's live location within a map of surveillance cameras, they are able to more clearly visualize the density & frequency of which they may intersect with the lenses of these cameras. The act of explicitly knowing & sensing these devices which may otherwise remain hidden & forgotten bring to light the issues of transparency & consent that the vast implementation of these cameras in public space raise. By engaging with this infrastructure knowingly while acting out day-to-day life and motion, folks who engage with this project are refuting the claim that they require such surveillance as they are not deserving of accusal or search based on their action - they offer a rebuttal this infrastructure evidence that watches them & asserts otherwise. Additionally, the ability to map out alternative routes to one's planned ventures that exceed the bounds of this video surveillance (or be faced with the fact that there is no alternate route), the vastness of these systems is re-enforced and the lack of ability to opt-out of such programs crystalized.
projects.background: The presumption of innocence states that "every person accused of any crime is considered innocent until proven guilty", this age-old principle has been enacted into the U.S. judicial system since the landmark 1895 case "Coffin v. United States" and remains the basis for such legal standards as "reasonable doubt" & "probable cause” which grant people in the U.S. protections from unreasonable search & unjust convictions. As just as this all sounds in theory, these ideals are evidently far from being upheld in practice. Growing up in a low-income Latino community & household during the early aughts, the enforcement & surveillance tactics used to act-out war on drugs era legislation were all to familiar & visible to me at school & at home. From being subjected to random K-9 drug searches during Biology class to witnessing the sneaky arrests of my classmates during lunch break & loved-ones at home, the exception to these protections have become all to familiar to me. For many other folks of identities and communities made marginal by capitalism and white supremacy, including Black, Brown, Indigenous, Immigrant, Muslim, LGTBQ, Latino and Low-Income communities, these exceptions are painfully clear. In Brooklyn, where this project lives, there is a vast history of over-policing and thus over-surveillance of its black communities; as just one example take the "Stop-and-frisk" program which targeted and harmed Black and Latino communities in Bed-Stuy contributing to a systemic violation of rights and over-representation in the area's jails and prisons. The implementation of digital and automated policing technologies such as video surveillance cameras, facial recognition searching, AI gunshot detection microphones and automated license plate readers (to name just a few) only complicate this legacy of inequity in the application of carceral power and judicial exception to which these communities are subjected to. While no single act or tool can undo the years and years of harm that these practices (which lead back to the period of enslavement and perhaps colonization) have cause or immediately unravel the infrastructure that supports them, Rebuttal Tracker aims to at least contribute to a growing public consciousness and refusal of these phenomena and call for support of efforts which directly act against them.
projects.technical_system: Front-end built with Geolocation API, OpenStreetMaps, a crowd-sourced dataset (GeoJSON) & plain HTML/CSS/JavaScript. Back-end is a secure Node.JS server on a Digital Ocean droplet authenticated with CertBot. R/Studio & QGIS were used for processing the dataset & creating location markers.

projects.project_name: I'm tired of cleaning your mess
projects.elevator_pitch: A human-robotic arm performance that explores the artist's frustration with technology
projects.description: Whether it's picking up a mirror toppled over by the roomba, or yanking a charging cord off a moving roomba, the artist is inspired by her daily struggle of cleaning up after failed automation. This performance explores the juxtaposition of when technology works wonders versus when it inevitably fails, and how humans have to intervene after such failures. Using a robotic arm, the artist highlights three different ways of how machines fail: machines realize their failures and awaits for further assistance, machines realize their failures and try to fix their own mistakes, and machines don't realize their failures and continue to function in dysfunctional manners. In creating this performance, the artist invites audiences to reflect on the increasingly omnipresent automation in our daily lives.
projects.technical_system: This performance is enabled by the MyCobot 280 Pi and its native python API developed by Elephant Robotics.

projects.elevator_pitch: Community Canvas is a website for New Yorkers to visualize new ideas for public spaces in 3D.
projects.description: Community Canvas is a web-based platform built to facilitate the first (idea generation) and second (project development) steps of the participatory budgeting (PB) process as implemented in NYC, particularly in the context of renovation, renewal, and repurposing of public spaces. Community Canvas invites users, i.e., community members, to express their ideas virtually using handheld devices to arrange accurate-to-scale 3D models in space. The Brennan Center for Justice identifies energetic and thoughtful outreach, clarity on what PB can and can't do, and giving residents actual control as among the key takeaways from interviews with citizens about the factors leading to PB's success. On the user end, Community Canvas presents an exciting new way to articulate ideas for how public space can be used, covering for the limitations of existing text- or map-based submissions. On the local government side, it provides an innovative means of outreach, through which representatives can not only keep constituents informed of the PB process through notifications, updates, and other important information about budget and PB limitations through the app interface, but also engage them through presenting a channel of direct communication with their representatives.

projects.project_name: Light: AI companion powered by therapy method
projects.elevator_pitch: Light, your AI companion for mental wellness. With our app, embark on a journey of self-discovery and growth through affordable, AI-guided sessions inspired by Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. Unpack your thoughts, reflect, and find solutions in a safe, therapeutic environment. Light ensures privacy while offering invaluable support. Start your journey today towards a brighter, healthier mind.
projects.description:
Light is an AI-driven voice chat App designed to serve as a companion who can help its users address their mental concerns through affordable and therapeutic solutions.

Inspired by Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) principles, the product leverages voice as its primary mode of interaction, guiding users through constructive sessions tailored to address their troubles and concerns. The experience positions users in a therapeutic environment in which they would gradually unpack their thoughts and reflect on their concerns by talking to the AI companion. It also aims to promote long-term growth by providing session summaries at the end of each session and using the history of the previous sessions to assist future conversations. The project aims to provide users with an educational tool to help them explore ways to self-reflect on their mental challenges and get a taste of talking therapy prior to necessitating professional medical intervention.

Light explores the potential of AI chatbots taking the roles of emotional companions in our lives. The project investigated the solutions for safeguarding user data privacy while effectively offering emotional support to the users.
projects.background: The inspiration for Light comes from a post I saw on reddit. Someone shared their experience asking ChatGPT to pretend to be their deceased father and talked to ChatGPT to say their last words. We have the tendency to become attached to a chatbot who is always available, but how to do that safely and effectively is still a question at stake. Light is my experiment towards this vision. In this project, I used ChatGPT and prompt engineering to create an AI chatbot who can guide its users through a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy session and conducted usability tests on several participants. The test yielded positive results - multiple participants expressed that they felt comforted after talking to the chatbot, despite that some of them were doubtful from the beginning. The following of the projects dive into the design of Light, and how different features could facilitate the interactions with the AI companion.
projects.technical_system:
Light utilizes large language models and their capabilities to reimagine how AI chatbot could become our daily companions. The project used ChatGPT and prompt engineering to prototype and test the interactions. The AI generated voice is created using ElevenLabs. 
Tools: Figma, Illustrator, Photoshop, After Effects

projects.elevator_pitch: My project aims to create interactive dioramas by incorporating sensors and technology to enhance user engagement through immersive experiences.
projects.description: The project is designed as an interactive diorama game that functions similarly to a board game. Players engage with the game by following audio instructions and visual cues to navigate and complete each level sequentially. This leveled structure ensures that players must clear one area before progressing to the next. The game concludes after players successfully complete the final level, providing a structured and immersive gameplay experience.
projects.background:
Whenever I am given the opportunity to be creative, I am consistently drawn to crafting miniatures. Their scale, whether diminutive or expansive, showcases the creator's prowess in animating a 'small world.' My fascination not only involves observing these intricate models but also interacting with them physically. This admiration sparked the concept for my final PCOM course project: an interactive miniature featuring three dynamic locations. Building on this foundational work, my current ambition is to scale this idea up substantially. I aim to evolve beyond mere mechanical interactions and LED displays; my vision is to weave storytelling, projection mapping, and Arduino-driven sensors into a narrative that mimics the immersive experience of a game or an escape-room-style board game.

To enhance the interactivity of my dioramas, I frequently explore YouTube and Arduino forums for innovative sensor applications. Additionally, I utilize visual guides from YouTube to master the art of crafting realistic miniatures, ensuring that each element not only represents, but actively contributes to the narrative journey.
projects.technical_system: This is a diorama game that uses magnet reed switches, photoresistors, and button/sliders for object interaction. These components will be separated and assigned to different Arduino nano33 devices based on the game areas. The Arduino devices will then send signals to a Unity server to trigger projection mapping from Madmapper. Since I am already using Unity, I may as well use it to play audio based on the player's decision. The current play-through of the game will be stored and tracked on the Unity server.

projects.elevator_pitch: “The Echoes Unheard” immerses audiences in an interactive digital soundscape that captures the poetic essence of marginalized dialects and the deep personal connections they hold for the artist. It unveils the rich artistic and cultural narratives hidden within these languages.
projects.description: “The Echoes Unheard” is a web-based interactive storytelling experience. It invites the audience into a virtual landscape crafted by the artist, guiding them through the whispered melodies created in marginalized dialects. This journey intertwines the poetic beauty hidden in these languages with personal echoes from the artist that pulse with the music. Through engaging with this digital landscape, the audience gains a deeper appreciation for the nuanced cultural narratives and the profound personal stories that resonate within the overlooked poetic essence of these languages. The experience culminates in an invitation for the audience to share a song of personal significance, rewarding them with a customized digital vinyl image as a souvenir of their journey.
projects.background:
"The Echoes Unheard" was inspired by the concept of "slow journalism," particularly Paul Salopek’s "Out of Eden Walk," which emphasizes storytelling through journaling about specific topics. This project sprouted from the desire to explore subjects deeply, leading to the discovery of music in unfamiliar languages and dialects. Such music, despite linguistic barriers, evoked profound emotions, sparking the idea to create a digital space that not only archives these musical pieces but also visualizes their invisible poetry and emotional connections with the artist.

This digital soundscape, built on Three.js, aims to offer an immersive experience that mirrors the slow journalism ethos, allowing the audience to engage with and reflect on the nuanced beauty of these songs. The built-in spatial audio feature in Three.js also enhances the immersion of the experience as the audience navigates in the space. The choice of technology was influenced by a review of similar projects, highlighting Three.js's ability to create engaging, interactive environments. "The Echoes Unheard" thus serves as a bridge between diverse musical expressions and the audience, inviting exploration of the rich cultural narratives and personal resonances embedded in the music.
projects.technical_system: The frontend utilizes HTML, CSS, and Vanilla JavaScript for the 2D user interface and Three.js for the 3D environment. The database for user responses is based on Google Firebase.

projects.elevator_pitch: How does our relationship with our personal technology change as the technology changes? Do we really have control over it, or do the companies making the technology control us?
projects.description:
In this intimate theatrical experience, you meet college student Alice who has volunteered for a Big Tech experiment - they have developed a chip they can implant in your brain that lets you then control the technology around you with your thoughts. The Big Tech Company is monitoring Alice’s chip’s functionality as it comes online by having her navigate a simple video game demo first with a game controller, and then with her thoughts. Throughout the whole encounter, you are in conversation with her about personal technology - do you control your tech or does your tech control you?

This is the first chapter in my decentralized, science fiction narrative experience, which at this time also includes a short Virtual Reality game following the same character.
projects.background:
Still need to flesh out:

- How can we use emerging technologies to augment theatrical experiences? How can we innovate in the immersive theater space?
- My research was primarily theoretical in the transhumanism, cybernetic, speculative fiction, and science fiction spaces, primarily through books (see further reading)
- Detours through octopus as non-human intelligence + other forms of this piece

projects.project_name: I'll Meet You at the Rainbow Bridge
projects.elevator_pitch: An evocative web-based virtual world designed to help individuals navigate the often-underestimated pain of pet loss.
projects.description: "I'll Meet You at the Rainbow Bridge" aspires to guide the solitary path of pet loss toward a shared journey of remembrance and healing. Born from a personal story of loss, this virtual sanctuary invites individuals to celebrate the lives of their beloved pets within a serene world. By merging the tangible act of memorialization with the realms of digital space, this project envisions a world where the grief of pet loss is shared, understood, and hopefully, a little easier to bear.
projects.background: Pets are family and having to let them go is a challenging emotion to navigate. For one, unlike other types of grief, societal norms often dictate that people ought to swiftly return to their routine following the loss of a pet, dismissing the depth of their grief. Yet, studies show that the sorrow felt from the passing of a pet mirrors the intensity of other forms of grief, with an increasing number of individuals turning to therapy for support. Inspired by the comforting concept of the Rainbow Bridge—a symbolic place of serene beauty where pets and their guardians reunite in joy—this web-based virtual world is intended for anyone who has lost a pet(s) at any juncture in their lives. Recognizing that grief is not a linear process, this thesis hopes to provide comfort to anyone in this situation irrespective of the temporal proximity to the event, and enable individuals to commemorate their departed companions by fostering a sense of solace derived from a community bound by shared experiences.

projects.elevator_pitch: Boundless is an exploration of PCB boards and LEDs as decorative, wearable art, and seeks to highlight the form factors of various electrical components rather than trying to embed or hide them behind other materials.
projects.description:
Boundless is an ongoing work combining high fashion aesthetics with hardware and wearable technology. The goal of this project is to create wearable, programmable circuit boards that also have a strong aesthetic sense, and utilize jewelry-making and craft techniques to solve electrical engineering problems. This series includes a large-scale chainmail-style PCB board dress, an LED pulsing PCB necklace, and a harness piece that accesses data via wifi to display planetary positions through LEDs. This project began as me seeking to create an LED grid with flexibility coming from linking together the LEDs in the manner of chainmail or jewelry, as opposed to mounting them on a flexible plastic or fabric surface. As the project evolved, I began incorporating PCB design as a surface to mount the LEDs on, and eventually, the PCBs as an essential  decorative part of the piece themselves. I really came to aesthetically appreciate the copper finish of DIY PCBs, which literally incorporates precious metals into the piece, as well as being functional for designing circuit boards. 
Marrying fashion aesthetics and jewelry-making techniques with elements more commonly associated with engineering is very important to me and this work. Boundless demonstrates how it's possible to solve technological and engineering problems with techniques dismissed as crafty or feminine, just as much as it’s possible to solve aesthetic and fashion problems with electrical elements.

projects.technical_system:
PLACEHOLDER - Full Details TK

Components used: 
White 5mm LEDs (64 for 8x8 grid)
Single-sided copper clad board 5x4 (x6)
Non-conductive silver chain (about 1 yd)
Arduino uno
Adafruit 16x8 LED Matrix Driver Backpack - HT16K33 Breakout
Solid-core wire

The circuit boards were designed in Autodesk Fusion, and milled using a Bantam Othermill Desktop CNC. Each circuit board design includes through-hole placement for an LED, routes placed vertically connected to the anode of the LED, horizontally connected to the cathode, with through-hole pads at each end of each route. Each of the four sides of the board had a 2.5mm hole in it connected to nothing electrically, to link the boards together for movement and support. 
The anodes of the LEDs in each column were connected via wire fed from the back of the boards through thru-hole pads, and soldered to the front to join everything electrically while minimizing the visibility of the wire. The cathodes of each row of LEDs were connected in the same way. Each row and column was then connected into the HT16K33 breakout, which was then connected to the arduino uno via I2C. (See wiring diagram per adafruit's documentation). The LEDs could then be programmed and controlled via the existing Adafruit HT16K33 backpack library. 

Adafruit HT16K33 backpack wiring and setup documentation: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-led-backpack/1-2-16x8-matrix-arduino-setup

projects.project_name: A Synthesis of Everything I Care About
projects.elevator_pitch: A tapestry of love testimonies on the spectrum of human and sacred experiences shared in a ‘confessional’ setting to foster connection in the very process of sharing and deep listening in the presence of another.
projects.description: I didn’t grow up religious but found my way into a church walking home from a visit with my sister. I was about 13. I remember being struck by the vastness of the incredible welcoming space; the stillness, the quiet, the quality of light emphasizing the beauty of the iconography - it filled me with awe and it spoke to me in a language that only my heart could decipher. Soon I was growing accustomed to the Christian Orthodox way of life. I remember my first Easter night service: tears streaming down my face and my heart jolting with joy for no apparent reason other than that of being alive. The only word that comes close to describing that experience is LOVE. I felt so close and connected to everyone around me even if they were strangers. It was during those years that I came across the passage in the 1 Corinthians 13: “Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It is not rude, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails.” I thought, what an ideal to live up to! Thesis delves deeper into this mystery. “What is it that we risk by making love our duty?” – is the question driving this research and it is explored through the concept of the mask that hold back from love, the sacrifice  – to overcome ourselves to meet the other, and the gift – which in the final analysis shows that even in the face of any perceived risk, love practiced as choice or duty, is that which blesses you.
projects.background: My Christian tradition, my studies of psychology and various spiritual texts, as well as my Buddhist trainings and practice of mindfulness and meditation, inform the symbolism of “The Confessional” setting that set the stage for the project. Confession is a ritual practiced by cultures across space and time, with the first documented examples of people coming to John the Baptist [as early as the first half of the first century CE], confessing their sins publicly and being baptized for the purpose of "repentance" and remission of sins as the goal. (Matthew 3:6, 11; Mark 1:5; cf. James 5:16) The act of repentance invites a deep investigation of self, coming to terms with parts of ourselves that are difficult to acknowledge even to ourselves (take masks down, sacrifice the ego), yet in doing so we become free from inner burdens (the gift) to then be able to feel more connected with life, with others, and open to love.

projects.elevator_pitch: Learn about electronics as if they were people, like us: with their own personalities, quirks, and roles in their system/society.
projects.description: Novices learning about electronics for the first time often face difficulties due to the abstract nature of the subject. Through anthropomorphism, the humanization of non-human entities. By attaching human qualities to electronic components. This leverages the cognitive bias to understand qualities and behaviors through metaphorical analogies to the human experience. Through a creatively designed comic book printed on the silkscreen of a Printed Circuit Board (PCB), electronic components are reimagined as characters with distinct personalities, quirks, and societal roles. This serves as both a visual guide and a functional example of the electronics at play, bridging the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical understanding.
projects.background:
Electronics, often perceived as an abstract and complex subject, presents a significant challenge to learners, especially those without a technical background. The application of narrative techniques in teaching electronics can transform this daunting subject into an accessible and enjoyable journey. Anthropomorphism, the attribution of human characteristics to non-human entities, serves as an effective bridge in this context. By humanizing electronic components within a story, learners can more easily grasp their functions and interactions.

In the realm of education, Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) has emerged as a key component, emphasizing the importance of emotional intelligence alongside academic skills. SEL advocates for understanding and managing emotions, setting positive goals, showing empathy for others, establishing positive relationships, and making responsible decisions. Integrating 

The integration of SEL, narrative learning, and anthropomorphism in the context of electronics education facilitates a deeper emotional and cognitive engagement with the material. This approach not only simplifies the complexities of electronics but also fosters empathy and a more profound connection with the subject matter. This results in a holistic learning experience that resonates on both an intellectual and emotional level, making electronics education approachable and comprehensible for a diverse range of learners.
projects.technical_system: KiCad, PCB Manufacturing, Illustration

projects.elevator_pitch: This project, named 1642, brings music to Rembrandt's painting, The Night Watch.
projects.description: This project, named 1642, brings music to Rembrandt's painting, The Night Watch. The painting was done in 1642 in Amsterdam, and it is one of the most famous and important paintings in Western art history. The project commences by breaking the painting into multiple layers. The bottom layer consists of the architecture in the background, followed by layers representing the characters from behind to front. Each person is digitally represented and painted. Throughout the painting of the background and layers, as well as the inclusion of intricate details, sound is being played simultaneously to provide audiences with a more immersive experience. The selected sounds are sourced from classical music in the Baroque era. the same era as the painting was created.The project necessitates extensive research into daily life in Amsterdam during the mid-17th century. An in-depth exploration of clothing and attire belonging to different social classes and occupations of that period is crucial, still, as the blocked figures in the back layers are also depicted.Ultimately, all 31 characters plus a dog allocate their specific spot, time, music, and unique representation. A script is written to organize the project, detailing the sequence of each layer, ensuring a harmonious fusion of visuals and sounds. The animation is projected at a 1:1 scale of the painting, measuring at 11' 11" x 14' 4". It is hoped that this immersive experience brings the audience a grander, theatrical, and dramatic encounter within the context of the combination of the visual splendor of Rembrandt in Dutch Golden Age and the timeless allure of classical music.

projects.description: In urban landscapes, towering structures and adorned windows weave a tangible web across the spaces that people inhabit, resembling a complex network. Screens, in their innate resemblance to windows, share a rectangular form, acting as frames or portals that bridge two or more realms. As a generation that grew up in cities and witnessed the development of the internet, I instinctively harbor suspicions about these connections. Because, at some point, whether in physical reality or digital reality, I constantly shift from one rectangular space to another. It's as if existence itself has been arranged and compartmentalized into boxes. It seems like we are online anytime, anywhere, and offline becomes an impossibility. I’m interested in the shifting and the overlapping between different boxes.

projects.elevator_pitch: Tangible Values is a digital gallery space for direct interaction with thought experiments, providing a dynamic environment for exploration and contemplation.
projects.description:
I am an over-thinker, but for the most part, it is because I like thinking. I wanted to use this project to share a part of what I like and to create a space for you to think about various things as well. This project is an interactive website with 3D elements that showcase 4 thought experiments and allow for people to act upon the decision presented in each thought experiment prompt.
Traveling past the introductory foyer, you will come across an onboarding experience demonstrated through the Dictator Game. Upon completion, I invite you to freely navigate to areas presenting the Volunteer Dilemma, Exchange Game, and Trust Game. In each area, a floating diamond will be your point of contact, revealing the area’s respective thought experiment prompt and relaying instructions on completing the corresponding interactive component.
The goal of this project is to make the experience of thought experiments more engaging by improving the tangibility of values upheld whilst thinking through the various scenarios. The implementations I have made are centered around adding interactivity to conventionally written text, using technology to showcase this experience visually in a digital realm and representing decisions made with actions taken. In making values more tangible, I hope to inspire reflection on what people care about and possible reasons behind their actions.
projects.background:
Why do I do the things I do? I deeply contemplate the motivations behind my behavior as a means of understanding myself, whether it’s an execution of values, an impulse of emotions, or a response to situational factors. These motives communicate both identity and tendencies, offering insights into the temporality of each passing state in which I exist. As such, I was happy to make a small part of that process - viewing actions as a window to our thoughts and feelings - a part of my project and share the same musings with other people.
I find particular interest in experimental games and thought dilemmas because they consist of base units of logic applicable across various contexts, while also yielding insights about a person in a light-hearted, hypothetical presentation. The controlled environment that thought experiments are depicted in minimizes the impact of situational factors and other persuasive contexts have on decision making. As a result, such decisions more closely represent our internal beliefs and typically take the form of an action in a situation.
However, the focus of the project, more broadly, is making the experience people have when engaging with thought experiments more robust. The implementations I have made to improve engagement are centered around adding interactivity to conventionally written text, using technology to showcase this experience visually in a digital realm and representing decisions made with actions taken. Through improving the tangibility of actions, these efforts give some tangibility to values upheld when thinking through the scenarios presented.
projects.technical_system: This project is written in React Three Fiber and uses the React Three Rapier physics library. Animations are handled with GSAP. From a 3rd person viewpoint, keyboard controls will be the primary method of engagement in this experience, along with some mouse interactivity. Chrome, glass, and monotone elements are used to portray reflectivity and honesty.

projects.elevator_pitch: Do Nothing Company a project centered around a conceptual company that hires people to practice doing nothing. We work through loving ourselves.
projects.description:
After a few years of exploring the theme of working culture, I initiated the project Do Nothing Company in 2024 as my thesis project. It is a project centered around a conceptual company that hires people to practice doing nothing. Currently, I am building it by using the Unreal Engine. In the Do Nothing Company’s virtual world, all the characters only play idle animations and remain inactive. Additionally, I would collaborate with a composer to create a piece of sound by exclusively using whistle sounds, a universal expression of joy or cheerfulness.
In 2024, where burnout is all too common, I wish to share the message to encourage people to embrace the power of doing nothing.

projects.elevator_pitch: An exploration of interactive design and generative arts. Allowing audiences to play with creature-like game systems and try and understand it.
projects.description:
Symbiosis is an exploration of interaction within generative arts. In the current landscape of generative art, we often see complex computative generated visuals but often have little or no means to interact with them or further understand them. Symbiosis aims to allow audiences to play with generative systems, observe and understand behaviors and patterns, and use that knowledge to create visuals unique to themselves. By using a generative design that mimics natural movement and concepts from nature, Symbiosis invites audiences to understand the visuals as if they were observing life in nature.

Symbiosis exists in two forms. As a web game and as an installation, by exploring different interactive mediums for the generative system I aim to use interactivity to recontextualize the artwork as a whole. Through different mediums and technologies, Symbiosis aims to explore the influence of technological mediums on our understanding of the content being presented to us.
projects.background:
I have been heavily influenced by many artists in the generative art space. Going as far back as “John Conway’s Game of Life” as an approach to generative artworks and cellular automaton. Aristid LIdenmayer’s book “The Algorithmic Beauty of Plants” uses context-free grammar as a means to create plant-like illustrations. “The Computational Beauty of Nature” by Gary William Flake My inspirations also come from modern artists such as Jonothan Zawada and his work on computational plants, Refik Anadol’s “Machine Hallucinations” visuals create a sense of complexity. Mark J. Stock and his usage of fluid motion in the generative process. These artists all use different forms of computational systems in their generative work. Rather than the visual output being the main focus, the focus lies in the logic of their works and provides me with a methodology for creating generative artworks. Some games which have inspired my research and visuals are ABZÛ, Journey and Antichamber. These games use minimal rulesets to control a complex system which in very little is spelt out to the player. These games invites the players to discover the world themselves rather than spelling it out for themselves.

My intention with this thesis is to try and explore other ways to apply computational thinking to visual artworks and add a layer of audience interaction to the piece. One of my main criticisms of the current generative art is the lack of interaction. Artists create complex generative algorithms only for audiences to not be able to inquire or play with them in any form. Through my thesis, I hope to be able to design a system that allows for participation in a meaningful way that lies in between a play/pause button and coding itself.
projects.technical_system: Generative description created with Javascript, GLSL, Three.js, OpenCV and Tone.js. There is also a physical interface using large inductive coils and wireless LEDs and tracks their positions with a camera.

projects.elevator_pitch: “Silent Whisper” —an immersive analogy of human societies to magnetic systems, advocating for the importance of external observation in understanding cultural and social dynamics
projects.description: “Silent Whisper” is inspired by my trip to Iceland. When I was standing among glaciers, in the middle of nowhere, I saw that time was frozen within it. The trail of wind, illustrated by volcanic ash, was compressed into the glacier layer by layer chronologically. With the absence of human societies, people were battered by the howling wind and snow, swaying like wild grass, which made me suddenly realize how small individuals are. Through interactive visual effects, physical installations, and multi-sensory experience, “Silent Whispers” reflects the relationship between people and invisible forces in their societies, which are so taken for granted that people mostly don’t realize they exist.
projects.background: In the text "The Crowd: A Study of the Popular Mind," Gustave Le Bon suggests that distancing oneself from the crowd facilitates critical thinking. Human societies are like a magnetism system. where individuals, much like particles, are continually drawn towards the stronger magnet. While some particles may escape the magnetic field as the system moves, they are easily recaptured by the magnetic force upon nearing it again. Humans, as vessels of their culture, education, and childhood experiences, can best engage in critical thinking by stepping back from their origins to assume the role of an observer. Consequently, I introduced a reversal of orientation in the interaction of visitors within the space. When audiences enter the space for a closer inspection of the magnetic system, they only perceive partial visual effects. However, when they choose to stand outside the space as witnesses, they can have a complete view.

projects.elevator_pitch: By storing DNA on a blockchain, where it can't be altered and is preserved forever, I've achieved digital immortality, living eternally within the blockchain. This project highlights the grotesqueness and eeriness of humanity's age-old desire for immortality.
projects.description:
"null" explores the perennial human yearning for immortality. Throughout various mythologies, it is evident that humans have contemplated the notion of immortality since ancient times. This pursuit continues today, with many wealthy individuals investing substantial amounts of money in immortality tech, making immortality startups a trending phenomenon. I, too, have been inescapably drawn to ponder over the concept of death.

Yuval Noah Harari, in his writings, posits that humanity's future direction is towards 'immortality.' He suggests that through cyborg technology, biotechnology, and smart drugs, humans are set to transform themselves, aiming for states of 'non-death' or becoming 'superhuman.' As immortality becomes increasingly tangible, my desire is to underscore the distortion and eeriness associated with it.

To this end, as an artistic representation of immortality's distortions, I will preserve my own DNA within the blockchain. The inherent nature of blockchain-recorded data, which becomes immutable and indestructible, serves this purpose.

By eternally storing my DNA on the blockchain, I aim to express 'digital immortality.' This method seeks to explore the possibility of continuing to 'exist' in some form even after death.
projects.background:
I used blockchain technology while working as a software engineer before enrolling in ITP. Blockchain fascinates me with its unique characteristic of enabling data to be permanently stored without any alterations, and I've always wanted to utilize this feature. Last year, I created a project that recorded the ephemeral eating experience through "Edible NFTs" on the blockchain.

https://www.instagram.com/p/Cth1eOvuLPX/?img_index=1

Leveraging blockchain's capability for permanent, unalterable data storage, I wanted to achieve immortality.

Siddhartha Mukherjee's "The Gene" profoundly influenced me, introducing me to the complexities and wonders of genetics.

HeLa Cells represent a form of immortality; these cells have proliferated and are now present in laboratories worldwide.

![Untitled](https://prod-files-secure.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/a054baf7-9b07-4155-b2a3-774cb08e4d6c/2c5cc2b4-6eba-4296-b85c-aec75f36d67e/Untitled.png)

 My work is also significantly influenced by Heather Dewey-Hagborg’s "Stranger Visions." As my Bioart class teacher, she provided deep insights into genetic-related issues and ethical questions.

projects.elevator_pitch: TBD
projects.description:
My thesis work is a movement-based investigation that seeks new ways of processing information to lessen the internal and external burden of our existence. It harnesses the power of collective thinking and collaboration through outsourcing sentiment – i.e., engaging the public to interpret the intentions and understand the emotional state of the subject. This investigation is conducted through digital self-manifestation and creation of a fully autonomous avatar, Notame.
 
This investigation will be presented in two forms: a physical artifact and a performance.
projects.technical_system:
The investigation process consists of several steps:
1) Motion capturing a series of movement improvisations: I captured a combined 40 minutes of two dancers’ movements (Shamar Watt and my own) that were based on different improvisation prompts, for example: “what does it feel like to not understand or feel good in your own body”, “how does the feeling of freedom expresses itself”, “how do you move when existing feels too difficult”. These prompts helped create a range of movements that span different emotional states.

2) Creating a movement database: All of the motion captured footage was retargeted onto an avatar, named Notame, and processed into a ~100 separate movements to create the foundation of the movement database. The movements’ length ranged from 4 to 20 seconds and expressed a range of emotions that came up in the improvisation sessions.

3)   Making the movement database publicly available: The movement videos are uploaded to a website for the public to engage with. This is the data collection step that uses “outsourcing of the sentiment”, where individuals on the web are invited to describe the quality or emotion of each individual move. This data collection process is part of creating a collective database of movement sentiments that will be the essence of the Notame’s emotions and movement evolution. At the end this process, each move will have  a set of corresponding crowdsourced words that express the collective understanding of that move.

4)   Creating a movement algorithm based on outsourced sentiment: The movement database will be used to create algorithmically generated movement sequences for Notame. This will be done in Unreal using sentiment analysis and Markov chains. This will allow Notame’s movements to be reflective of the two dancers but it’s autonomy and decision making will be driven by the collective sentiment.

This investigation will be presented in two forms: a physical artifact and a performance.

The physical artifact is a book of movement that contains a collection of 56 movements that are in the database. Each page of the book will have physically written words that correspond to the public sentiments collected for each of the moves. The avatar’s movement will be projected on top of the written sentiment, thereby breaking the boundary between the physical and the virtual. The book will be an archival piece that consist of 100 pages, where every time you turn the page the corresponding movement will be projected onto the words (see a prototype below).

The second part of the investigation will be presented in form of a performance. The performance is a movement-based conversation between me and Notame (the avatar) that happens at the boundary of physical and virtual space. The performance will use a combination of live motion capture and avatar’s projection with real-time movement sequencing in Unreal.

projects.elevator_pitch: In our fast-paced world, Gadgets to Live By invites you to pause—simple yet significant reflection through design.
projects.description:
"Gadgets to Live By" is a project born from the intersection of technology, personal experience, and the quest for pursuing mental well-being. This collection of gadgets emerges as a deliberate counter to the relentless pace of digital consumption and the often overlooked emotional landscapes navigated in our daily lives. Central to the project are two gadgets: "Haiku News" and "Decision Maker," each designed with the purpose of integrating technology into our lives in a way that promotes reflection and mental health.

"Haiku News" reimagines the way we consume news by transforming anxiety-inducing headlines into tranquil haiku poetry, displayed on an e-paper screen. This gadget offers a meditative pause from the bombardment of traditional news, providing a reflective space that encourages contemplation and emotional distance from the explicit and subjective realities portrayed in the media. "Haiku News" addresses the impact of information overload on our mental health, offering an alternative that soothes rather than stimulates anxiety.

The "Decision Maker" gadget responds to the indecisiveness that can often accompany mental health struggles. Combining the whimsy of a magic eight ball with the excitement of a slot machine, it not only entertains but also provokes thoughtfulness for the user, challenging them to reflect on the questions they pose and assist with the decisions they face in everyday life.

Designed, 3D printed, and assembled with care, these gadgets are not just tools but companions in the journey of life, offering insights and interventions in moments of need. "Gadgets to Live By" stands as a testament to the power of thoughtful design in creating gadgets that doesn't just occupy space in our lives but enriches it, fostering well-being, reflection, and a deeper engagement with the world around us.
projects.technical_system: Each of these gadgets were designed in Fusion, 3D printed, and then assembled by hand. Haiku News is powered by Adafruit's Feather board, e-paper display, NFC chip, and Decision Maker is powered by Raspberry Pi.

projects.elevator_pitch: This research and, ultimately, the art piece explores the evolving concept of magic, from a tool and practice for understanding the unknown to a word for describing complex technologies. An immersive installation, featuring AI-generated nature visuals, invites visitors to embrace this magic state of mind,  forgotten knowledge and fosters a reconnection with nature.
projects.description:
Stepping barefoot onto a bed of earth in a darkened room, the hushed hum of an ambient soundscape washes over you and a light in the center invites you. An open umbrella becomes a portal, its surface alive with ever-evolving, AI-generated visuals. 

This art piece is part of a larger research into the intrinsec relations between magic, technology, humans and nature. Magic is a constant presence in our lives as humanity, helping us understand the world and connect with it. It’s meaning changed extensively over time and I now try to understand: What is magic? What defines a magic experience? Why do we talk about technology in terms of “magic”? What are the mechanisms of power incited by this vocabulary?

This multisensory immersive installation invites interactors to practice a state of presence, creativity and contemplation state of mind to reimagine our connections with nature, technologies, with our ways of engaging with the world around us and, ultimately, with this mysterious and broad concept of magic.
This piece aims to bridge Artificial intelligence, the lastest "magic"-evoking trend of technology, with the most primitive awe-inspiring "magic" of nature itself with its own technologies that inspired us as humanity.
projects.background:
Magic, once a way for early humans to grasp the unknown, morphed into a powerful practice.  It fueled alchemists' dreams of transforming materials and garnered praise for magicians.  However, the rise of religion demonized this "forbidden knowledge," particularly when wielded by women.  Magic, once a source of hope, became synonymous with witchcraft.

This societal shift mirrors Bruno Latour's "Great Divide" – the separation of progress from nature.  Ironically, our most advanced technologies, like artificial neural networks, are inspired by nature's own ingenious designs.  Technology builds upon the foundation laid by natural processes.  Even scientists like Isaac Newton embraced the mystical alongside the academic, recognizing the interconnectedness.

The language of magic has re-emerged with the rise of complex, awe-inspiring technologies.  Just as magic was ostracized, then embraced by alchemists, so too are powerful computers seen as both fearsome and profitable.  The ostracized knowledge of witches becomes the foundation for advancements.  The installation aims to bridge this divide, using the magic of AI to celebrate the magic of nature.  By reimagining the relationship between technology, nature and magic, we move beyond fear and towards a creative thinking that honors the knowledge inherent in all.

Stable Diffusion (AI generated visuals)

Projection Mapping

William A. Stahl “Venerating the Black Box: Magic in Media Discourse on Technology”

projects.elevator_pitch: An interactive website showcasing opinions on 'Fate' from people with diverse backgrounds.
projects.description:
I suffered great changes in my life over the past few years. Having lost much that was important to me, I began to contemplate life introspectively. I'm not religious, and I don't have something to pray for every time I feel lost and stuck. Sometimes I'm just genuinely curious, is there truly something called fate? Then, when I'm suffering, it doesn't necessarily mean I did something wrong. 'Fate' sometimes can be a vent or excuse for me to escape. For my thesis, I decided to delve deeper into the concept of 'Fate'. This website showcases all those deep explorations.

I interviewed people and transformed their thoughts about 'Fate' into an interactive website to showcase different opinions on this topic.
projects.background:
Based on my personal experiences, I have become increasingly curious about how people's opinions on 'fate' are shaped by their backgrounds and experiences. Therefore, my primary research involved conducting a survey. In this survey, I asked approximately 40 people a range of general and detailed questions. I aimed to explore the potential connections or randomness between people's opinions on fate and factors such as their religious beliefs, significant life changes, or age.

In addition to this, I conducted research on Chinese traditional fortune-telling, which is related to my cultural background. In my opinion, the way a culture practices fortune-telling reflects their perspective on fate and, more broadly, their understanding of the essence of the world. Inspired by yin yang philosophy, I decided to incorporate the ba gua as a primary visual element for my website. This choice conveys a sense of reincarnation, which aligns with my views on 'Fate'.
projects.technical_system: The main languages I used for this thesis are HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. For the interactive parts, I utilized p5.js, and for the 3D elements, I employed three.js.

projects.elevator_pitch: This project redefines signatures from static marks to dynamic expressions, animating individual traits into living identities. By challenging traditional perceptions, it explores the deep connections between identity, creativity, and visual representation, sparking dialogues on human complexity and digital artistic innovation.
projects.description:
For centuries, signatures have served as a symbolic extension of our identity, appearing on contracts, artwork, and personal documents. Signatures have served as more than just a means of authentication; they are reflections of our identities, beliefs, and creativity.

Imagine a signature evolving beyond its static form, becoming an animated representation of the individual behind it. This project delves into the concept of signatures embodying facets of our personality, transforming them into living organisms that reflect individual character traits.

By infusing signatures with subtle animations and distinct visual styles, each signature takes on a personality and movement, mirroring the diversity and nuances of the individuals they represent. This exploration seeks to redefine how we perceive signatures, turning them into dynamic expressions of identity rather than static marks on paper.

Furthermore, this endeavor seeks to challenge conventional notions of signatures as mere legal marks, instead reimagining them as vibrant expressions of identity and self-expression. It invites viewers to ponder the deeper connections between identity, creativity, and the visual representation of one's persona.

Ultimately, this project aims to spark conversations about the multifaceted nature of human identity and the endless possibilities of artistic expression in the digital age.
projects.background: This project draws inspiration from graphology and studies in drawing and linguistic analysis, such as the New York Times article “Kiki or Bouba?”. While graphology is considered unreliable for determining personality traits solely based on handwriting, this project draws inspiration from translating handwriting qualities to animations. The "kiki/bouba" effect, where certain words are associated with specific visual qualities, is another influence. Similarly, this project pairs visual signature qualities with personality traits, translating them into animated representations.
projects.technical_system: This project utilizes p5.js to capture user signatures via a touchscreen, translating them into vector points. The signatures undergo analysis based on attributes like stroke count, average angle, and point distance. These characteristics are stored in a JSON server, and signatures are displayed on a large screen with animations reflecting their unique traits.
